text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.
To find out more, visit our website.
6MuteEnglish
from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello and welcome to 6MuteEnglish. I'm Alice.
So Rob, what job did you want to do when you were little?
speaker: Alice

text: Oh, I really wanted to be an astronaut.
Being orbit, watching the Earth from afar.
Wow, be in orbit. It means be in space and following the Earth's curvature.
Well, the view must be nice from up there.
But the reality of becoming an astronaut is pretty hard.
And it's the subject of today's show.
Did you know that less than 600 people have been into space so far?
I'd like to have been one of them.
I know I have what it takes to be a space man.
Yes, there are many others like you who would like to go for this job, Rob.
And that's the quiz question for you today.
OK. Well, I asked: How many people have applied to join NASA's 2017 astronaut class? Was it… a) 800, b) 8,000 or c) 18,000 people?
speaker: Alice

text: Was it A, 800, B, 8000 or C, 18000 people?
8000 sounds like a lot already.
So I'll go for B, 8000 people.
Well, we'll find out if you chose the right answer later on in the programme.
Well, we'll find out if you chose the right answer later on in the programme. So, what do you think is the biggest challenge when considering becoming an astronaut?
speaker: Alice

text: claustrophobia
speaker: Alice

text: And that means fear of being in a small space.
That might be a problem because the space capsules are small and you're with the same people
for months at a time.
Yes, that's right. Well, astronauts are bound to get on each other's nerves sometimes! To get on someone's nerves means: to annoy them.
speaker: get on someone's nerves

text: To get on someone's nerves means to annoy them.
But I'm a great team player… so I think I'll be OK.
speaker: Rob

text: Yes, I can confirm that.
Anyway, the challenge of being an astronaut doesn't stop here.
In the space capsule, astronauts have to put up with extremely difficult conditions,
like zero gravity, for example.
Yeah, it looks like funding some assaults in the capsule and catching bits of food in your mouth
as it floats out of its packet.
But zero gravity, a condition where gravity is exerting no force,
can lead to wasting of the bones and muscles.
Astronauts take two and a half hours of exercise per day to help prevent this.
But what do astronauts have to do before they go into space to prepare themselves for weightlessness and spacewalking?
speaker: Rob

text: and spacewalking?
They can practice using a virtual reality headset and special gloves.
It's like playing a computer game that looks and feels like doing a spacewalk.
And they also train in a swimming pool.
Let's listen to Major Tim Peek, a British astronaut talking about the preparation he did
for his mission on the International Space Station.
The way we practice spacewalking is in water.
Water gives us the neutral buoyancy that we need.
So we sink training modules into swimming pools and then practice the spacewalking on them.
We wear very specific equipment, a pressurized space suit.
Very difficult to move in, actually.
It's hard to bend the fingers, it's hard to bend your arms and it really gives you quite a difficult workout.
British astronaut Tim Peek says water gives us buoyancy, which is the ability to float.
Floating in space is similar to floating in water.
So astronauts practice their spacewalk in swimming pools.
Yes, they take to the water and to the air too.
Astronauts experience the feeling of weightlessness in planes.
A large plane with padded walls flies to high altitude and then goes into a nose dive
or a fast and sudden fall, which creates short periods of weightlessness.
Fabulous! I'd love to do that!
speaker: Rob

text: But it's not all fun and games.
Don't forget that one of the main reasons for being out on the International Space Station
is to conduct research.
Major Tim Peek is doing scientific experiments such as how to grow plants in space
and what effect radiation and zero gravity have on this process.
Like that film where an astronaut gets stranded – or left behind – on Mars and has to grow potatoes.
speaker: stranded

text: and has to grow potatoes, the film's called the Martian.
That's right, yes.
So do you think you have what it takes to survive in a challenging environment, Rob?
Let's listen to Major Tim Peek talking about his survival training.
Survival training, and for this, the European Space Agency send us to Sardinia.
When you land in the Soyuz capsule, sometimes you might not land exactly where you expect to be.
Foraging for food, for example, and your basic elements of shelter and protection,
getting water, going live in a cave for seven days with an international crew.
And it's a wonderful environment to prepare you for a mission because you are very isolated.
So astronauts may get stranded on Earth – when the space capsule lands somewhere unexpected. And they have to find food. Forage means to search.
speaker: Forage

text: and they have to find food.
Forage means to search.
It's a word we often use to describe how animals search for food.
speaker: Alice

text: Indeed.
Well, let's go back to that quiz question you asked me earlier, Alice.
Indeed. Well, let's go back to that quiz question you asked me earlier, Alice. I'm keen to know how many people want to live this experience of being an astronaut.
speaker: Rob

text: Okay, well, I asked how many people have applied to join NASA's 2017 astronaut class?
Was it A, 800, B, 8000 or C, 18000 people?
Hmm, am I so quite a lot at B, 8000 people?
And you were wrong, I'm afraid.
According to NASA's website, more than 18,300 people applied to join their 2017 astronaut class.
This is almost three times the number of applications received in 2012 for the most recent astronaut class.
Wow! So there's no chance of me ever succeeding.
speaker: Rob

text: Oh, well, you mustn't give up, Rob.
Oh, well, you mustn't give up, Rob. Anyway, we are running out of time so here are the words we heard today:
speaker: Alice

text: In orbit, claustrophobia, get on someone's nerves, zero gravity,
buoyancy, nose dive, stranded, forage.
Well, that's the end of today's six minute English.
Please join us again soon.
Bye.
speaker: Both
